get.description: Suggests example utterances that would improve the accuracy of the intent model in a version of the application.

200.description: If there's no trained intent model, nothing is returned in the response. If there's a trained model and active learning finds any relevant queries, they are returned with the intent model predictions. If there's a trained model but active learning didn't find any relevant queries, an empty list is returned in the response.

parameters.name: entityId
parameters.description: The target entity extractor model to enhance.

200.description: If there's no trained entity model, nothing is returned in the response. If there's a trained model and active learning finds any relevant queries, they are returned with the entity model predictions. If there's a trained model but active learning didn't find any relevant queries, an empty list is returned in the response.

get.description: Exports a LUIS application to JSON format.

200.description: The LUIS application structure in JSON format.

post.description: Sends a training request for a version of a specified LUIS app. This POST request initiates a request asynchronously. To determine whether the training request is successful, submit a GET request to get training status. Note: The application version is not fully trained unless all the models (intents and entities) are trained successfully or are up to date. To verify training success, get the training status at least once after training is complete.

202.description: This response indicates the initial training status.

get.description: Gets the training status of all models (intents and entities) for the specified LUIS app. You must call the train API to train the LUIS app before you call this API to get training status. "appID" specifies the LUIS app ID. "versionId" specifies the version number of the LUIS app. For example, "0.1".

200.description: A successful response provides an array of training status details for a LUIS app that you submitted for training. Each element in the response array provides training status for a model (intent or entity) in the LUIS app. Note: Training status is not provided for prebuilt entities because they are pretrained. The "modelId" property identifies which intent or entity the training status corresponds to. To get the name and type of each model, use the models API which has a request URL in this format: https://westus.api.cognitive.microsoft.com/luis/api/v3.0-preview/apps/{appId}/versions/{versionId}/models The details property for each model can contain the following fields: "statusId": An integer from 0 to 3 that corresponds to the value of the status field. "status": A string with one of the following values: "Success", "UpToDate", "InProgress", "Fail". If the status is "Fail", the "failureReason" property provides the reason for failure. "exampleCount": The number of examples used for training. In the case of the None intent or prebuilt domain intents and entities, this number includes example provided internally by the system as well as examples you added to your LUIS app. "failureReason": A string that indicates the reason training failed.  The value "FewLabels" means that no labeled example utterances were provided for training. "trainingDateTime": A string indicating the time the model was last trained. The value uses the ISO 8601 format for representing times in UTC (Coordinated Universal Time) with a UTC designator ("Z"), for example: "2017-08-10T01:08:34Z".

get.description: Exports a LUIS application to text format.

200.description: The LUIS application structure in LU format.

schema.description: The LUIS application structure in LU format.

EntityLabelObject.description: Defines the entity type and position of the extracted entity within the example.

startCharIndex.description: The index within the utterance where the extracted entity starts.

endCharIndex.description: The index within the utterance where the extracted entity ends.

role.description: The role the entity plays in the utterance.

children.description: The identified entities within the example utterance.

ApplicationCreateObject.description: Properties for creating a new LUIS Application

culture.description: The culture for the new application. It is the language that your app understands and speaks. E.g.: "en-us". Note: the culture cannot be changed after the app is created.

domain.description: The domain for the new application. Optional. E.g.: Comics.

description.description: Description of the new application. Optional.

initialVersionId.description: The initial version ID. Optional. Default value is: "0.1"

usageScenario.description: Defines the scenario for the new application. Optional. E.g.: IoT.

name.description: The name for the new application.

PrebuiltDomainCreateBaseObject.description: A model object containing the name of the custom prebuilt entity and the name of the domain to which this model belongs.

PrebuiltDomainCreateObject.description: A prebuilt domain create object containing the name and culture of the domain.

culture.description: The culture of the new domain.

PhraselistCreateObject.description: Object model for creating a phraselist model.

phrases.description: List of comma-separated phrases that represent the Phraselist.

isExchangeable.description: An interchangeable phrase list feature serves as a list of synonyms for training. A non-exchangeable phrase list serves as separate features for training. So, if your non-interchangeable phrase list contains 5 phrases, they will be mapped to 5 separate features. You can think of the non-interchangeable phrase list as an additional bag of words to add to LUIS existing vocabulary features. It is used as a lexicon lookup feature where its value is 1 if the lexicon contains a given word or 0 if it doesnt.  Default value is true.

enabledForAllModels.description: Indicates if the Phraselist is enabled for all models in the application.

SubClosedList.description: Sublist of items for a list entity.

canonicalForm.description: The standard form that the list represents.

SubClosedListResponse.description: Sublist of items for a list entity.

activated.description: Indicates if the Pattern feature is enabled.

activated.description: Indicates if the feature is enabled.

words.description: List of comma-separated phrases that represent the Phraselist.

mode.description: An interchangeable phrase list feature serves as a list of synonyms for training. A non-exchangeable phrase list serves as separate features for training. So, if your non-interchangeable phrase list contains 5 phrases, they will be mapped to 5 separate features. You can think of the non-interchangeable phrase list as an additional bag of words to add to LUIS existing vocabulary features. It is used as a lexicon lookup feature where its value is 1 if the lexicon contains a given word or 0 if it doesnt.  Default value is true.

enabledForAllModels.description: Indicates if the Phraselist is enabled for all models in the application.

PhraselistUpdateObject.description: Object model for updating a Phraselist.

phrases.description: List of comma-separated phrases that represent the Phraselist.

isActive.description: Indicates if the Phraselist is enabled.

isExchangeable.description: An exchangeable phrase list feature are serves as single feature to the LUIS underlying training algorithm. It is used as a lexicon lookup feature where its value is 1 if the lexicon contains a given word or 0 if it doesnt. Think of an exchangeable as a synonyms list. A non-exchangeable phrase list feature has all the phrases in the list serve as separate features to the underlying training algorithm. So, if you your phrase list feature contains 5 phrases, they will be mapped to 5 separate features. You can think of the non-exchangeable phrase list feature as an additional bag of words that you are willing to add to LUIS existing vocabulary features. Think of a non-exchangeable as set of different words. Default value is true.

enabledForAllModels.description: Indicates if the Phraselist is enabled for all models in the application.

ApplicationPublishObject.description: Object model for publishing a specific application version.

isStaging.description: Indicates if the staging slot should be used, instead of the Production one.

versionId.description: The version ID of the application that was exported.

culture.description: The culture of the application. E.g.: en-us.

versionId.description: The version ID of the application that was exported.

culture.description: The culture of the application. E.g.: en-us.

The utterance. For example, "What's the weather like in seattle?"

roleId.description: The role id for the predicted entity.

score.description: The intent's score, based on the prediction model.

phrase.description: The actual token(s) that comprise the entity.

FeaturesResponseObject.description: Model Features, including Patterns and Phraselists.

FeatureInfoObject.description: The base class Features-related response objects inherit from.

id.description: A six-digit ID used for Features.

isActive.description: Indicates if the feature is enabled.

enabledForAllModels.description: Indicates if the feature is enabled for all models in the application.

isExchangeable.description: An exchangeable phrase list feature are serves as single feature to the LUIS underlying training algorithm. It is used as a lexicon lookup feature where its value is 1 if the lexicon contains a given word or 0 if it doesnt. Think of an exchangeable as a synonyms list. A non-exchangeable phrase list feature has all the phrases in the list serve as separate features to the underlying training algorithm. So, if you your phrase list feature contains 5 phrases, they will be mapped to 5 separate features. You can think of the non-exchangeable phrase list feature as an additional bag of words that you are willing to add to LUIS existing vocabulary features. Think of a non-exchangeable as set of different words. Default value is true.
